Award.AwardTitle: MRI:Acquisition of a Beckman ProteomeLab-XLI Analytical Ultracentrifuge to Enhance Research and Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Utah State University to acquire a new Beckman ProteomeLab XLI analytical ultracentrifuge (AUC) to support research and training. The AUC will support the research programs of seven different laboratories and be available to other users within the university and neighboring institutions. At USU, the instrument will be used to provide hands-on training in cutting-edge molecular techniques to undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral researchers, and become an integral part of the educational and outreach efforts in the Chemistry and Biochemistry department.

The analytical ultracentrifuge will be used to study the in solution properties of macromolecular complexes including determining accurate molecular weights, heterogeneity and stoichiometry. At USU, the analytical ultraentrifuge will be used to support the research of the PI and Co-PI's to investigate: (1) the mechanism of action of ATP-dependent motor proteins; (2) the assembly of Type III secretion systems in pathogens; (3) the oxidation based control of proteins; (4) the assembly mechanism of RNA; (5) the Iron protein cycle; (6) antimicrobial action of amphiphilic aminoglycosides; and (7) the development of therapeutics for Amyloid Diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding provided by the National Science Foundation was used to purchase an analytical ultracentrifuge (AUC) that is housed in the Department of Chemsitry and Biochemistry at Utah State University. This AUC is a highly specialized piece of equipment that has allowed investigators at USU and collaborating institutions to determine accurate molecular weights, heterogeneity, and stoichiometry of proteins that play important roles in human diseases including bacillary dysentary and heart disease as well as critical cellular processes including nitrogen fixation and DNA repair mechanisms.

More specifically, data recently collected on the AUC was critical to a study uncovering details about how Shigella bacteria inject effector proteins into human cells to cause infection and evade immune responses. The findings from this study have been published in the Journal of Biological Chemistry and additionally have been presented by students at multiple conferences, providing them with the opportunity to meet other scientists and discuss their research. 

Additional findings driven by students in research labs at USU inlcude uncovering the stoichiometry of a methylation enzyme that appears to be involved in histone modification and likely DNA transcription efficiency. This finding was uncovered because of the availability of the AUC to the research lab and is now a major research focus of several graduate students in the lab. 

In the spirit of collaboration, the AUC is available not only to USU researchers, but to labs across the country, including the Antony lab at Marquette University who recently used the instrument to support their findings describing the dynamics of the DNA binding protein, RPA, with single stranded DNA durring repair of damaged DNA.

Finally, the instrument has been used heavily as a teaching tool for both undergraduate and graduate students enrolled in a class focusing on biophysical characterization methods. The students are taught about the theory of AUC in the classroom and are then provided the opportunity to perform AUC analysis on a protein sample of their choosing. This hands on training for how to operate the instrument and analyze the resulting data is a great "real life" scenario that is both preparing the students for employment following graduation and helping them to become familiar with the method so that they can incorporate AUC in their graduate research programs.
